standard_metadata.standard_description: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction by a whole number.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Multiply unit fractions and whole numbers

hints.content: Let's figure out how many times we add $\dfrac{1}{12}$ to make $\dfrac{7}{12}$ .

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-twelfths to seven-twelfths, with labeled tick marks at every one-twelfth unit. Above the number line, a blue arrow jumps right from zero-twelfths to one-twelfth, then to each one-twelfth unit to the end of the number line at seven-twelfths. Above each jump is the label plus one-twelfth.

hints.content: Let's figure out how many times we add $\dfrac{1}{3}$ to make $\dfrac{4}{3}$ .

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-thirds to four-thirds, with a labeled tick mark at every one-third unit. Above the number line, a blue arrow jumps right, starting at zero-thirds to one-third, then to each one-third unit to the end of the number line at four-thirds. Above each jump is the label plus one-third.

hints.content: Let's figure out how many times we add $\dfrac{1}{10}$ to make $\dfrac{3}{10}$ .

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-tenths to three-tenths, with a labeled tick mark at every one-tenth unit. Above the number line, a blue arrow jumps right, starting at zero-tenths to one-tenth, then to each one-tenth unit to the end of the number line at three-tenths. Above each jump is the label plus one-tenth.

hints.content: Let's figure out how many times we add $\dfrac{1}{6}$ to make $\dfrac{5}{6}$ .

Above the number line, a blue arrow jumps right, starting at zero-sixths to one-sixth, then to each one-sixth unit to the end of the number line at five-sixths. Above each jump is the label plus one-sixth.

hints.content: Let's figure out how many times we add $\dfrac{1}{2}$ to make $\dfrac{11}{2}$ .

Above the number line, a blue arrow jumps right, starting at zero-halves to one-half, then to each one-half unit to the end of the number line at eleven-halves. Above each jump is the label plus one-half.

hints.content: Let's figure out how many times we add $\dfrac{1}{5}$ to make $\dfrac{4}{5}$ .

Above the number line, a blue arrow jumps right, starting at zero-fifths to one-fifth, then to each one-fifth unit to the end of the number line at four-fifths. Above each jump is the label plus one-fifth.

hints.content: Let's figure out how many times we add $\dfrac{1}{4}$ to make $\dfrac{5}{4}$ .

Above the number line, a blue arrow jumps right, starting at zero-fourths to one-fourth, then to each one-fourth unit to the end of the number line at five-fourths. hints.content: $\blueD{\text{What number}}$ can we add $9$ times to make $\dfrac98$ ?

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-eighths to nine-eighths, with a labeled tick mark at every one-eighth unit. Above the number line, a blue arrow jumps right, starting at zero-eighths to one-eighth, then to each one-eighth unit to the end of the number line at nine-eighths. Above each jump is the label plus one-eighth.

hints.content: $\blueD{\text{What number}}$ can we add $2$ times to make $\dfrac23$ ?

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-thirds to 1, with tick marks at every one-third unit. Above the number line, a blue arrow jumps right from zero-thirds to one-third and then from one-third to two-thirds. Above each jump is the label plus one-third.

hints.content: $\blueD{\text{What number}}$ can we add $7$ times to make $\dfrac76$ ?

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-sixths to seven-sixths, with a labeled tick mark at every one-sixth unit. Above the number line, a blue arrow jumps right, starting at zero-sixths to one-sixth, then to each one-sixth unit to the end of the number line. Above each jump is the label plus one-sixth.

hints.content: Let's figure out what $\dfrac{2}{5}+ \dfrac{2}{5} + \dfrac{2}{5} + \dfrac{2}{5}$ equals.    [[☃ image 1]]    $\dfrac{2}{5}+ \dfrac{2}{5} + \dfrac{2}{5} + \dfrac{2}{5}= \dfrac{8}{5}$

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-fifths to eight-fifths, with tick marks at every one-fifth unit. Above the number line, a blue arrow jumps right from zero-fifths to two-fifths, from two-fifths to four-fifths, from four-fifths to six-fifths, and then from six-fifths to eight-fifths. Above each jump is the label plus two-fifths.

hints.content: Now, let's figure out how many times we add $\dfrac{1}{5}$ to make $\dfrac{8}{5}$ .    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-fifths to eight-fifths, with a labeled tick mark at every one-fifth unit. Above the number line, a blue arrow jumps right, starting at zero-fifths to one-fifth, then to each one-fifth unit to the end of the number line at eight-fifths. Above each jump is the label plus one-fifth.

hints.content: Let's figure out what $\dfrac{3}{4}+ \dfrac{3}{4}$ equals.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\dfrac{3}{4}+ \dfrac{3}{4} = \dfrac{6}{4}$

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-fourths to six-fourths, with tick marks at every one-fourth unit. Above the number line, a blue arrow jumps right from zero-fourths to three-fourths and then from three-fourths to six-fourths. Above each jump is the label plus three-fourths.

hints.content: Now, let's figure out how many times we add $\dfrac{1}{4}$ to make $\dfrac{6}{4}$ .  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-fourths to six-fourths, with a labeled tick mark at every one-fourth unit. Above the number line, a blue arrow jumps right, starting at zero-fourths to one-fourth, then to each one-fourth unit to the end of the number line at six-fourths. Above each jump is the label plus one-fourth.

hints.content: Let's figure out what $\dfrac{3}{2}+ \dfrac{3}{2} + \dfrac{3}{2}$ equals.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\dfrac{3}{2}+ \dfrac{3}{2} + \dfrac{3}{2} = \dfrac{9}{2}$

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-halves to nine-halves, with  tick marks every one-half unit.  Above the number line, a blue arrow jumps right, starting from zero-halves to three-halves, from three-halves to six-halves, and then from six-halves to nine-halves. Above each jump is the label plus three-halves.

hints.content: Now, let's figure out how many times we add $\dfrac{1}{2}$ to make $\dfrac{9}{2}$ .   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-halves to nine-halves, with a labeled tick mark at every one-half unit. Above the number line, a blue arrow jumps left to right, starting at zero-halves to one-half, then to each one-half unit to the end of the number line to nine-halves. Above each jump is the label plus one-half.

hints.content: Let's figure out what $\dfrac{4}{3}+ \dfrac{4}{3}$ equals.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\dfrac{4}{3}+ \dfrac{4}{3} = \dfrac{8}{3}$

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-thirds to eight-thirds, with tick marks at every one-third unit. Above the number line, a blue arrow jumps right from zero-thirds to four-thirds and then from four-thirds to eight-thirds. Above each jump is the label plus four-thirds.

hints.content: Now, let's figure out how many times we add $\dfrac{1}{3}$ to make $\dfrac{8}{3}$ .    [[☃ image 1]]

hints.content: Let's figure out what $\dfrac{5}{12}+ \dfrac{5}{12} + \dfrac{5}{12}$ equals.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\dfrac{5}{12}+ \dfrac{5}{12} + \dfrac{5}{12} = \dfrac{15}{12}$

hints.content: Let's figure out what $\dfrac{5}{4} + \dfrac{5}{4}$ equals.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\dfrac{5}{4}+ \dfrac{5}{4} = \dfrac{10}{4}$
